thread.title: Father beats son as Stephen Kenny enjoys winning return to Dundalk
thread.title_full: Father beats son as Stephen Kenny enjoys winning return to Dundalk

author: James Rogers
title: Father beats son as Stephen Kenny enjoys winning return to Dundalk
text: Stephen Kenny enjoyed a winning return to Oriel Park thanks to second half goals from Tom Grivosti and Mason Melia after his son Eoin had briefly threatened to spoil the party. This was just a second away win of the campaign for St Patrick’s Athletic and their first since beating Galway Utd on the opening day. While it is a huge boost to their hopes of getting back into Europe following their run to the Europa Conference League play-offs, the defeat leaves Jon Daly’s Dundalk rooted to the bottom. While this game in hand could have seen them leapfrog neighbours Drogheda Utd, the Co Louth club have perhaps more pressing concerns ahead amid local reports that owner Brian Ainscough is set to pull his investment just over nine months after acquiring the keys to Oriel Park. It’s a far cry from the heights Dundalk reached under Stephen Kenny’s reign with the former Republic of Ireland boss guiding the Lilywhites to four league titles, two FAI Cups and the group stages of the Europa League prior to departing for the international setup almost six years ago. This was his first time back managing against his old side but his return threatened to be spoiled when his son Eoin fired the home side in front after just 79 seconds. Dan Pike’s long throw was helped on by Hayden Cann allowing the 18-year-old to nod past Joseph Anang from close range. Despite that bright start, it was the visitors who had the bulk of chances to level in the period afterwards with Felix Goddard flirting with disaster on a number of occasions with Brandon Kavanagh, Aidan Keena and Jake Mulraney all going close to catching out the on loan Blackburn Rovers goalkeeper following unforced errors. St Pat’s finally found a way past him within 10 minutes of the restart as a free kick was headed down by Joe Redmond for his centre back partner Grivosti to hook the ball to the net past a statuesque Goddard. The visitors then hit the front on 68 minutes when Mulraney’s cross from the right was bundled over the line by Melia. Goddard ; Pike, Boyle, Cann, Mountney; Dervin (Keane 87), Benson (Gullan 69); Horgan, Hakiki (McGill 69), O’Kane (Garbett 75); Kenny (Mahon 75). Anang; Sjoberg, Redmond, Grivosti, Breslin; Lennon, Forrester; Elbouzedi, Kavanagh (Bolger 83), Mulraney (McClelland 72) Keena (Melia 62). Damien MacGraith (Mayo).
